--- Mitchell Timin <zenguyuno@...> wrote:
> These are very preliminary results.  The results I
> reported were against a totally random opponent.  

Ah...well, for some reason I thought throughout the
entire discussion of Concentration that the players
would be playing solitaire.  That's probably where I
would have started with this domain.

It's easier to code, for one.  And then you don't have
to worry about relative fitnesses and multiple
populations, at least until you want to add them in. 
If the player is just playing solitaire, your fitness
function is trivial...it's just how many turns it
takes for the player to clear the board. 

> They appear to be evolving against each other, but I
> have no way of know how good they are!  The
> first-movers are winning about 60% of the games and
> the 2nd movers about 40%.  They might all be playing
> near-perfect games or all just about like random
> players.

Well, Ken posted a link to give you some ideas.  There
are lots of different ways to test them, but a pretty
easy one would just have them play solitaire (like
playing an opponent who always passes).  If there's no
statistical difference between the number of turns it
takes your nets and random players to clear the board,
then your algorithm isn't working.

Honestly, 60% wins for a first-mover sounds pretty
close to random, and part of the problem is the small
domain.  The probability of finding a match with only
six cards is reasonably high, and after a match is
made, the odds of matching go up even more.

It would be easier to mark progress in a game with
more cards, because your random players are really
going to suck as the number of cards gets big.

> That is an unforeseen problem with co-evolution; you
> can't easily tell how they are doing if the evolve
> together.  I need to add some objective measure
> because I like to know what's happening.  I won't
> use
> that for evolution, just for observation.

Like I said, solitaire should do the trick.  Or
alternately, if each of your evolved players is played
multiple times against a random opponent, playing at
least two games, with each player taking turns going
first, then your nets should win more games if they're
doing anything.  

Derek
